thesis.description: Spray drying may be defined as the drying of an atomized solution or slurry in contact with a stream of hot gases, under conditions which permit the recovery of the dried product.
thesis.creator: Pinder, Kenneth L.
thesis.subject: Chemical Engineering.
thesis.title: the Fundamentals of Spray Drying
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The Heat Pump, as a device to provide low grade heat for conditioning purposes, is generally considered to have been originated by Lord Kelvin and its description was contained in papers presented by him in 1852 (75). The original papers described a system capable of transferring heat from a cold temperature to a higher one. Since air was to be the refrigerant, large volumes were required and his cylinder volume was to be 15.63 cubic feet. Power to drive the unit was to be provided by a steam engine and thus was of little practical use.
thesis.creator: Phillips, Lorne A.
thesis.subject: Engineering.
thesis.title: Operating Characteristics of a Diesel Driven Heat Pump.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: An extensive investigation of blood preservation, plasma 'substitutes' and the survival of blood cells after transfusion has been carried out in the Department of Biochemistry, McGill University, since the first months of World War II, under the direction of Dr. O.F. Denstedt and with the financial support of the National Research Council of Canada and, more recently, of the Defence Research Board of Canada.
thesis.creator: Pappius, Hanna Maria (Kwiecinska).
thesis.subject: Biochemistry.
thesis.title: Metabolism of Erythrocytes During Storage.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The diagnosis of infectious diseases is based upon the isolation and identification of the infecting organism. At times it is difficult or even impossible to isolate the causative organism and one has to rely upon serological methods for diagnosis. Infections by Mycobacterium tuberculosis present a special case. [...]
thesis.creator: Nommik, Salme.
thesis.subject: Immunology.
thesis.title: Results of the Dubos-Middlebrook Hemagglutination Test in Human Tuberculosis.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The Ordovician palaeontology and stratigraphy of the Churchill and Nelson Rivers, Manitoba are described. In addition, the unfossiliferous Silurian(?) rocks are divided into formations, but no attempt is made to correlate them.
thesis.creator: Nelson, Samuel J.
thesis.subject: Geology.
thesis.title: Ordovician Palaeontology and Stratigraphy of the Churchill and Nelson Rivers, Manitoba.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: This work, the third in a series on white spruce bark, is concerned with the unsaponifiable portion of the ether extractives of the bark. Research on these extractives was begun because bark is a major waste product of the Canadian pulp and paper industry, difficult to dispose of and yet an obvious source of a wide variety of organic substances. It is hoped, of course that accurate knowledge of the chemical substances present in the extractives will lead eventually to their commercial utilization.
thesis.creator: Murdock, James David
thesis.subject: Biology.
thesis.title: Sterols and Terpenes from Spruce Wood Bark
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: During the past ten years, the importance of the phenomenon of enzymtic adaptation has beoome more and more apparent. Besides being in itself of considerable interest, it possesses implications for general cellular physiology extending outside of the area in which adaptation was originally studied, that of variations in micro-organisms. Thus, advances in our understanding of genetic mechanisms have already been made through studies of enzymatic adaptation. It has been predicted that further knowledge of enzymatic adaptation will throw light on some of the mechanisms of cellular differentiation in animal tissues. Arguments have been advanced to link adaptive enzyme formation with detoxication mechanisms and antibody formation in higher animals.
thesis.creator: Kushner, Donn J.
thesis.subject: Chemistry.
thesis.title: Studies on Enzymatic Adaptation in Micro-Organisms.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Preliminary experiments were conducted at Macdonald College to study variation in root development of one barley variety at different stages of growth and seventeen varieties at one stage. Comparisons were based on total root dry weights, root numbers and top-root ratios. O.A.C. 21 roots reached their maximum weight and variability was least when the first spike had completely emerged. Top-root ratios of O.A.C. 21 were lower and root weight relatively greater under normal winter daylengths than under 16-hour photoperiods. Correlations between maturity and root weight, and maturity and root number, of seventeen barley varieties were significant. Top-root ratios were not correlated with maturity but appeared to be associated with the relative moisture requirements of different varieties. Variation within varieties was such that only large differences between varieties were significant. Light intensity during the winter was not optimum for barley plant growth.
thesis.creator: Klinck, Harold Rutherford.
thesis.subject: Biology.
thesis.title: Variation in Root Development of Barley.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: This investigation is concerned with neutron deficient isotopes of cadmium and silver which have been produced by (p,xn) reactions in the McGill 100 Mev synchrocyclotron.
thesis.creator: Johnson, Frederick Allan.
thesis.subject: Chemistry.
thesis.title: Investigation of Radiations from New Cadmium and Silver Isotopes.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The revolutionary advances in textile technology during recent decades, including new processes, new finishes, and new fibers, have created the need for some means of predicting the performance of fabrics under actual wear conditions. The ultimate criterion of fabric quality is performance under wear conditions. Thus it becomes of considerable importance to devise rapid laboratory treatments that will simulate the actual conditions of wear. The importance attached to this problem is evident from the vigorous current attempts to set up international standards; from the number of organizations, governmental and private, engaged in instrumenting and perfecting textile tests; and from the demands of consumer groups for reliable information on the cloth they buy.
thesis.creator: Jenkins, Marjorie McMillen.
thesis.subject: Chemistry.
thesis.title: A Study of the Accelerated Ageing of Rayon Textiles.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The investigation to be reported in this thesis forms a part of an integral study of erythrocyte preservation which is being carried on under the direction of Dr. O. F. Denstedt in the Department of Biochemistry at McGill University. In January 1940, under the stimulus of World War II, this research was begun with the object of improving the known methods of preservation and administration of whole blood. The continuity of this research has been made possible by the sustained interest of the National Research Council, the Defence Research Board, the John and Mary Markle Foundation, and the Baxter Laboratories of Canada Ltd.
thesis.creator: Jacobs, Ross Dougall.
thesis.subject: Biochemistry.
thesis.title: Study of Diphosphopyridine Nucleotide in the Erythrocytes.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: A method for the preparation of thin films of selenium by means of vacuum evaporation is described. Films deposited on thin glass and quartz plates were used in the spectrographic observation of absorption in the visible and ultraviolet regions of the spectrum. Films deposited on the compensating plates of the Michelson interferometer were used in measuring the refractive index of selenium at four wave-lengths. Measurements of reflection and transmission were made at various wavelengths with a photomultiplier tube.
thesis.creator: Hunten, Janet Lucia.
thesis.subject: Physics.
thesis.title: Some Optical Properties of Thin Films of Selenium.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The operation known as prefrontal lobotomy has in the past fifteen years become a new source of information as to the function of the human frontal lobes. Other sources have been animal experimentation, and clinical cases of tumor or abscess, and accidental injury. In all of these cases the evidence has been difficult to interpret. In some respects, certainly, the evidence provided by lobotomy may be even harder to interpret, and it is not likely that it will lead immediately to the solution of a difficult problem - the localization of function in the frontal lobes - but the operation provides new and important data to put beside what has been learned from other sources. It originated with the experimental work of Jacobsen, who demonstrated an alteration in the emotional behavior of chimpanzee following ablation of the frontal areas, and this led Egas Moniz to the hypothesis that patients with mental illness would be benefited by the division of the fibers from the thalamus to the frontal lobes.
thesis.creator: Hoyt, Ruth.
thesis.subject: Psychology.
thesis.title: Intelligence in Schizophrenic Patients with Lobotomy.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: In previous studies on benzimidazole (1), the chemistry and pharmacology of the compound were presented. Prior to this work, the pharmacology of benzimidazole was contributed by the work of Goodman (2) and Goodman et al. (3), who observed that the injection of benzimidazole to laboratory animals produced complete paralysis of the skeletal musculature. In the brief review presented here, the chemistry and pharmacology of benzimidazole will be discussed in relation to the present study of the influence of benzimidazole on enzyme systems.
thesis.creator: Hosein, Esau Abbas.
thesis.subject: Chemistry.
thesis.title: theInfluence of Benzimidazole on the Metabolism of Tissue Preparations of the Rat.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: New gamma activities assigned to isomeric states of Pb201 (50+/- 1 sec.) and Pb202 (5.6 +/- 0.1 sec.) are produced by proton bombardment of thallium in the McGill cyclotron and have been studied by a sodium iodide scintillation spectrometer. Assignments are based partly on chemical separation and partly on thresholds of production. [...]
thesis.creator: Hopkins, N.J.
thesis.subject: Physics.
thesis.title: Scintillation Spectrometry with Sodium Iodide Crystals.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: It has long been known that silica is present in all vegetable and animal tissues. Most of it appears to be in a soluble form which is readily absorbed by the gut and excreted in the urine. A considerable fraction is also present in the skin, hair and other tissues. But the state of its occurrence is not known. The observation from spectroscopic analyses performed in our laboratory a few years ago, that silica is invariably present in the hard tissues and tends to be much higher in certain organs, prompted the present study, with a view to establishing whether there is a functional metabolism of silicon, or whether its presence is merely accidental. [...]
thesis.creator: Hollett, Charlotte.
thesis.subject: Chemistry - Biochemistry
thesis.title: Studies on the Absorption and Excretion of Silicon.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: A simple analyser employing an electric field between parallel planes has been designed and found satisfactory for obtaining the energy spectra of secondary electrons. An automatic system has recorded energy spectra from evaporated copper and silver targets. These curves have exhibited two principal maxima at energies linearly dependent upon the primary voltage. The interpretation is that in each of two successive interaction processes, primary electrons have lost the same fraction (characteristic of the metal) of their effective energy. Separation of the spectra into two components has provided a graph of probability of energy transfer from primary to secondary. [...]
thesis.creator: Harrower, G.A.
thesis.subject: Physics.
thesis.title: The Energy Spectra of Secondary Electrons from Copper and Silver.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Comparative growth studies on twelve linseed varieties of flax were conducted over three dates of seeding tests during two growing seasons.
thesis.creator: Hansen, D.R.
thesis.subject: Biology.
thesis.title: Differential Growth Rates in Flax Varieties and their Relation to other Plant Characters.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The Thetford-Black Lake area, Megantic County, Quebec, has been one of the most important producers of chrysotile asbestos for over 60 years. The asbestos has been obtained either from a large mass of partly serpentinized peridotite, thought to be laccolithic in shape, or from a narrow body of serpentinized peridotite that parallels the structural trend of the area, known as the Pennington Dyke. The mines and open pit workings of the larger mass have always encountered light-coloured holocrystalline dykes which vary in composition from a diorite to a quartzitic vein, but which are always referred to by the miners and mine operators as "granite". Small deposits of chromite are found in the same mass, associated with an olivine-rich phase of the peridotite. Here again, "granite" dykes are encountered, although not as extensively as in the asbestos workings. The object of this thesis is, by the study of published reports on these acidic intrusives and with the help of some original studies, to report on their petrographic character and their distribution, and draw conclusions as to their age, origin, and economic importance.
thesis.creator: Gorman, W.A.
thesis.subject: Geology.
thesis.title: Acid Intrusives of the Thetford Mines - Black Lake Area, Que.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The small number of berries reaching maturity in Smilacina racemosa, and their few-seeded condition, invited a reinvestigation of the embryology. The embryo sac development had previously been reported by McAllister in 1913. Modern knowledge of fruit formation, of apomictic development, and of endosperm-embryo relationships, have enabled a more inclusive study than was possible in the previous investigation.
thesis.creator: Gorham, Anne L.
thesis.subject: Biology.
thesis.title: Development of the Female Gametophyte and Embryo in Smilacina racemosa (L) Desf.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The progress made by science for humanity has brought with it an aging population and attending this an ever increasing incidence of arteriosclerosis. This disease is beginning to play a serious role in the world so that it is now the commonest cause of death in the older age group. It therefore becomes imperative to deal with the problem. Many advances have already been made in this field of experimental research. Of these the importance of the serum lipid interrelationships in the geneais of experimental atheroscleroais have been repeatedly emphasized. [...]
thesis.creator: Gordon,Dina.
thesis.subject: Health Sciences - Pathology
thesis.title: the Effect of Prolonged Cortisone Treatment on Normal Rabbits and on the Development of Experimental Atherosclerosis in Rabbits.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The science of Meteorology has made remarkable advances during the past century. What were formerly unrelated natural phenomena are now seen as a part of a naturally developing whole. In this respect, the snow crystal, one of nature's major environmental conditioners, is in the process of exhibiting an ordered development only hoped for twenty years ago.
thesis.creator: Gold, L.W.
thesis.subject: Physics.
thesis.title: On the Relation of Snow to Meteorology.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The word data has a connotation of impersonal objectivity "untouched by human hands". The data in this study, however, have personal histories, and many boys and girls have participated in helping experience become data.

thesis.subject: Social Work.
thesis.title: Factors Influencing Dual Membership in Two Group Work Agencies.

thesis.description: The writings of Machiavelli and Hume are separated by two and a quarter centuries. There is no doubt that the intellectual climates of Renaissance and Enlightenment, the political problems of Italy and England ~ and the social positions of Machiavelli and Hume were important elements in the formation of their respective philosophies. It is undeniable that certain aspects of their thought can be better understood in terms of the historical context in which they lived. [...]
thesis.creator: Frankel, Saul.
thesis.subject: Economics.
Political Science.
thesis.title: Machiavelli and Hume as Forerunners of Modern Political Thought
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The question of the nature of time is as old as philosophy, and has continuously engaged the attention of philosophers up to the present time. Heraclitus, Plato, Leibnitz, Schopenhauer, and Eddington are only a few of the thinkers whose speculations have been intimately concerned with the problem of time. For Kant, all experience involves time as an a priori necessity. Bergson makes a distinction between the linear time of the physicist and biological time--a process of accumulation and creative change.[...]
thesis.creator: Falk, John L.
thesis.subject: Psychology.
thesis.title: Some Factors Affecting the Judgment of Temporal Intervals
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.
